snippet.title: Salesforce Picks BlueJeans For First Video Integration. But It's Complicated
snippet.description: This week is DreamForce, the Salesforce.com extravaganza that will see a reported 120000 people descend on San Francisco for the week. The announcements are coming thick and fast and tomorrow sees CEO Marc Benioff take the stage for one of his legendary (and epic) keynotes. It's always nice to be able to break [...] read »

snippet.title: Brooks Brothers Should Get Grilled For Its Steakhouse Plan
snippet.description: Brooks Brothers invented apparel retailing for America's ruling class, back before being rich was synonymous with looking and acting like Paris Hilton, and then watched Tommy Hilfiger and A&F turn its brand position into a reality show in which any of us could participate. It has since experimented with an [...] read »

snippet.title: The True Story Behind Bobby Thomson's 1951 Jersey
snippet.description: This story appears in the May issue of ForbesLife magazine, dated May 21. It is a sidebar to a story on investor Dan Scheinman's collection of historic baseball uniforms. Bobby Thomson's 1951 New York Giants uniform. Dan Scheinman, a former Cisco Systems senior executive, bought his most famous piece from Bobby Thomson himself in [...] read »

snippet.title: Workplace Fashion SOS: Quick And Unexpected Fixes For Apparel Disasters
snippet.description: A few short years ago, as an employed, rent-paying 25-year-old, I bought myself my first truly expensive pair of shoes. They were Kate Spade, knee-high, four-inch black boots and set me back about $350. I was in love. So in love that I justified the expenditure and its serious dent [...] read »

snippet.title: Hey, Have You Ever Noticed This?
snippet.description: I was recently attending a baseball game at AT&T Park when I got a pleasant surprise: a friend of many years was making his way to a seat right in front of mine. He looked in my direction; I smiled at him. Then he sat down without acknowledging me. My [...] read »

snippet.title: Exit Stage Left: Possible Societal Costs if the Economy Fails to Recover
snippet.description: By Marco Rabinowitz While the US economy continues to hobble its way back towards recovery, I think it is important that we keep in mind the sociological context of the current financial crisis and to where it could evolve if the economy fails to recover.
